Name: Program Planning in Family and Consumer Education
Description: Theory and processes of program planning for formal and informal educational settings; relation of vocational education to secondary, adult, and continuing education programs.

Name: Student Teaching in Family and Consumer Education
Description: Supervised student teaching at the middle and high school levels.

Name: Leadership and Management of Nonprofit Organizations
Description: Survey of leadership and management roles and methods to achieve key organizational functions and enable nonprofit organizations to fulfill their role in civil society.

Name: Special Topics
Description: Special Topics

Name: Community Leadership
Description: Explores community building and community action strategies for renewing fragmented connections in today's localities. Builds knowledge and skills for participation and leadership at team and multi-stakeholder community levels in the context of nonprofit organization work.  Requires 5 hours of service learning.

Name: Community Based Research and Evaluation
Description: Theoretical, critical, and analytical understanding and application of the conscious and systematic use of data, inquiry and analysis for community, organization and program diagnosis, intervention and evaluation in various community-based and nonprofit organizations.

Name: Parent Education and Support Programs
Description: The purposes, contexts, and implementation of parenting support and education programs are studied. Some sections may include a service learning component.

Name: Independent Study
Description: Independent Study

Name: School-Community Engagement
Description: Critical examination of school-community engagement and collaboration. Examines theory and practice of mutually beneficial collaboration in diverse education settings, including leadership issues in collaborative settings, and facilitators and inhibitors to effective collaboration.

Name: Research Methods
Description: Basic techniques: questionnaires, interviews, behavioral observation, sampling, experimental designs and data analysis using computer. Students learn to write a research proposal with literature review.

Name: Special Topics in Human Ecology
Description: Special Topics in Human Ecology at the Master's and Doctoral levels. Subject matter varies.

Name: Seminar Family Ecology
Description: This seminar is focused on professional development and practice skills grounded in a human ecology perspective, which is typically seen as the engaged application of arts and sciences to issues affecting life quality.

Name: Seminar: Research Design and Methodology
Description: For students actively involved in designing, analyzing, and writing up research projects or theses.

Name: Evaluation for Administrative Decision Making in Education
Description: Theory and methods of evaluation for administrators. Models and techniques related to educational needs assessment, program and product development, formative and summative evaluation. Use of evaluative information for administrative decision making and administration of educational evaluation projects.

Name: Research and Thesis
Description: Research and Thesis

Name: Independent Study
Description: Independent Study

Name: First-Year Seminar in the Biological Sciences
Description: Interdisciplinary course for first-year students. Topic will vary with instructor and will be announced in the Timetable. Enrollment limited.

Name: First-Year Seminar in the Humanities
Description: Interdisciplinary course for first-year students. Topic will vary with instructor and will be announced in the Timetable. Enrollment limited.

Name: First-Year Seminar in the Social Sciences
Description: Interdisciplinary course for first-year students. Topic will vary with instructor and will be announced in the Timetable. Enrollment limited.

Name: First-Year Seminar in the Social Sciences and Natural Sciences
Description: Interdisciplinary course for first-year students. Topic will vary with instructor and will be announced in the Timetable. Enrollment limited.

Name: Approaches to Critical Thinking and Writing
Description: None provided.

Name: Ways of Knowing: Medicine and Society
Description: Sophomores are exposed to a variety of scholarly topics on subjects dealing with medicine and society by campus-wide faculty. Discussions led by faculty who are primary care practitioners. Students are encouraged to explore the possibility of a research experience in their degree program.

Name: L&S Career Development: Taking Initiative
Description: Interdisciplinary course in career development that connects the liberal arts and sciences degree to academic and career preparation, practical job skills, goal-setting, critical thinking and reflection. Designed for second year students, but open to all students.

Name: Undergraduate Research Experience
Description: Participation in research or creative endeavor led by faculty or instructional staff and in undergraduate Research Scholars Program. This course may also include participation in research discussion groups, critiques of readings, and preparation of written or oral reports.

Name: Internship in the Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Enables students with outside internships to earn academic credit connected to their work experience, regardless of their major. Using online tools, students collaboratively analyze and discuss their internships with respect to the goals of a liberal arts and sciences education.

Name: Paradigms and Process in Academic Inquiry
Description: Designed specifically for the research fellow, this course offers a structure for thinking about research that avoids reducing research to a single mode of thought and practice, and is thus inclusive of the range of approaches to research reflected in Inter-LS 250. Will address specific topics that relate to the day-to-day activities of doing research, and addresses issues of what does it mean to think like a researcher, to act like a researcher, to talk like a researcher?

Name: L&S Junior/Senior Seminar
Description: Interdisciplinary course for juniors and seniors. Topic will vary with instructor and will be announced in the Timetable. Enrollment limited.

Name: Public Humanities: Theories, Methods, Cases
Description: The aim of this course is to introduce graduate students to a range of methods, theories, and cases that represent the emerging field of the public humanities and to prepare graduate students to explore the range of opportunities that exist for them outside of academia. Students in the seminar will be expected to read, practice, and experiment. The course will focus on the limits, audiences, and outcomes of research in the humanities, including the possibility of translational research. The final project will involve the design and in some cases implementation of a project based upon your scholarly research. Students will undertake out-of-classroom projects and exercises in addition to reading.

Name: International Business
Description: A survey of the interrelationships of world business operations; an introduction to current conceptual perspectives; cultural, educational, political and economic constraints, the international financial and trade frameworks, and the problems and challenges facing the multinational corporation.

Name: Professional Communication and Culture in the Francophone World
Description: Study and analysis of the culture and sociology of professional environments in the French and Francophone worlds, including government, international organizations, NGO's and business. Students develop communication skills through interactive teaching methods in multimedia labs.

Name: Contemporary Issues in Government, Organizations, and Enterprise
Description: Cultural study of contemporary Francophone Africa, focusing on issues in government, organizations and enterprise. Exploration of cultural and professional relations between Francophone Africa and France, the European Union, and the United States.

Name: Advanced Interdisciplinary Studies in Professional Communication
Description: In-depth study, from interdisciplinary perspectives, of key aspects of technical French language for the professions and business, together with an exploration of the history, sociology, and culture of professional environments in the French and Francophone worlds.

Name: Intercultural Communication in Business
Description: Develops awareness and knowledge of cultural influences on business. Focuses on various attitudes toward work, time, material possession, business, and the relationship of these attitudes to different social, religious, philosophical, and educational backgrounds of business people from cultures around the world.

Name: Spanish for Business
Description: Spanish lexicon and linguistic style for management, banking, accounting, capital investment, personnel and office systems, production of goods and services, marketing, finance, and import/export; includes translation and interpretive activities.

Name: Contemporary Topics
Description: A course for the exploration of subject areas possibly to be introduced into the business curriculum.

Name: Reading and Research-International Business
Description: None provided.

Name: Global Issues in Management
Description: This course focuses on the strategic management required in global business. Topics include environmental analysis, global strategy, and subsidiary control. The aim of the course is to develop special skills that are required to manage international firms.

Name: Global Marketing Strategy
Description: Structure of foreign trading; commercial facilities available to exporters and importers; application of economic analysis in marketing decisions; contemporary trends in international economy affecting foreign trade policies and practices.

Name: International Real Estate
Description: Analysis of international real estate and related transaction issues, especially in foreign countries which are visited as part of the course; survey of land use patterns and regulations, ownership rights, types of leases, transfer procedures, mortgage system, tax matters, currency risks, and geographical diversification issues.

Name: Multinational Business Finance
Description: Application of financial theory to the operations of multinational firms; survey of the international financial environment; determinants of international portfolio and direct investment capital flows; management of foreign exchange position and hedging strategies; evaluation of foreign investment projects (multinational capital budgeting); international financial structure decisions; multinational credit institutions and capital markets; taxation of international business.

Name: Latin American Economic Development
Description: A historico-institutional analysis of development problems in the principal Latin American countries, with attention to differentiation of national growth patterns and alternative development strategies.

Name: Multinational Business Finance
Description: Theory of business finance as applied to the operations of multinational firms; financial analysis and control of foreign investment decisions; working capital management; multinational credit institutions and capital markets; special accounting problems and trends in international monetary affairs.

Name: Contemporary Topics
Description: None provided.

Name: Reading and Research-International Business
Description: Individual work suited to the needs of graduate students may be arranged both during regular sessions and the intersession periods.

Name: Introduction to International Studies
Description: Familiarizes students with the field of international studies, and performs an interdisciplinary examination of the cultural, political, economic, and social patterns that have defined the modern world.

Name: Global Language Issues
Description: A series of modules, each showcasing one language and its culture. Each module tackles a major issue about language, such as extinction and revival, language and nationhood, how widely and deeply languages differ, language and wordview, writing systems and literacy, language discrimination and inequality.

Name: WIScholars: Wisconsin International Scholars Program Seminar
Description: Discussion of international events and topics designed specifically for WIScholars Program participants, geared toward fostering leadership skills.

Name: International Learning Community Seminar
Description: A 1-3 credit class graded on a Credit / No Credit basis which addresses various international, cross-cultural and language topics of interest to the residents of the International Learning Community.

Name: The Politics of Human Rights
Description: Examines the origins and development of human rights in international politics. The course discusses what human rights are, international human rights movements, the international search for justice after mass crimes, and international humanitarian intervention.

Name: The Comparative Study of Genocide
Description: Examines the phenomenon of genocide in the modern world. The class covers the concept of genocide, theories of why genocide occurs, and particular cases in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Name: Contemporary Issues in International Studies
Description: Topics vary. Course may be repeated but not with same content.

Name: Washington DC Semester in International Affairs Internship Seminar
Description: Washington DC internship in international affairs. Open to program participants only.

Name: Indian Politics in Comparative Perspective
Description: This course explores the socio-economic and political outcomes across India. This course will employ the major theories of comparative politics that explain political outcomes such as regime type, economic development and conflict. This course explores why some countries are democracies, while others are dictatorships; why some countries are poor, while others are rich; and why some countries experience high levels of violence, while others are peaceful. The course considers how India comports with standard theories in comparative politics and how standard theories might be revised in light of the Indian case. The course maps variation on the sub-national and regional level. The course will ultimately consider reforms proposed by the Indian state to further democratic and economic development and to reduce conflict. Students will learn about India's politics in a structured manner, and will gain an appreciation of the power and limitations of the political science method.

Name: Globalization and Education
Description: Introduces students to the origins, development, and debates in the field of globalization and education (GE); explores educational experiences in settings around the world; and examines how GE studies and approaches can inform learning, teaching, and research practices.

Name: Globalization, Poverty and Development
Description: Addresses the process of globalization -- trade, international capital flows, labor migration and remittances, and aid -- from the perspective of developing economies and the development process.

Name: The Growth and Development of Nations in the Global Economy
Description: This course explores the roles of markets, states, and civil institutions, using economic theory, computer simulations, and historical experience to better understand the forces that shape the wealth and well-being of nations and people around the world.

Name: Topics in Global Security
Description: Contemporary issues in international studies in global security. Topics vary. Course may be repeated but not with the same content.

Name: Topics in Politics and Policy in the Global Economy
Description: Contemporary issues in international studies in politics and policy.  Topics vary.  Course may be repeated but not with the same content.

Name: Topics in Culture in the Age of Globalization
Description: Contemporary issues in international studies in global culture. Topics vary. Course may be repeated but not with the same content.

Name: Social Mobilization in Latin America
Description: This course serves as an introduction to the major empirical and theoretical themes in the study of mobilization in Latin America.

Name: Contentious Politics
Description: Social movements, revolutions, and riots continually shape and re-shape the world around us. The course will evaluate and apply dominant theoretical approaches to understanding contention through careful attention to empirical cases throughout the world.

Name: The Politics of Human Rights
Description: Examines the origins and development of human rights in international politics. The course discusses what human rights are, international human rights movements, the international search for justice after mass crimes, and international humanitarian intervention. Enroll Info: Not open to students with credit for POLI SCI 317 prior to fall 2017

Name: The Comparative Study of Genocide
Description: Examines the phenomenon of genocide in the modern world. The class covers the concept of genocide, theories of why genocide occurs, and particular cases in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Name: Study Abroad Topics in Global Security
Description: Course reserved as a course equivalency for topics courses done in conjunction with Study Abroad.

Name: Study Abroad Topics in Politics and Policy in the Global Economy
Description: Course reserved as a course equivalency for topics courses done in conjunction with Study Abroad.

Name: Study Abroad Topics in Culture in the Age of Globalization
Description: Course reserved as a course equivalency for topics courses done in conjunction with Study Abroad.

Name: Study Abroad Topics in Global Environment
Description: Course reserved as a course equivalency for topics courses done in conjunction with Study Abroad.

Name: Study Abroad Topics in International Studies
Description: Course reserved as a course equivalency for topics courses done in conjunction with Study Abroad.

Name: International Internship
Description: Course reserved as a course equivalency for topics courses don in conjunction with study abroad.

Name: Women's Global Health and Human Rights
Description: This course will take a human rights approach to global women's health to provide an overview of health issues within the context of a woman's life cycle. It will pay special attention to the socio-cultural and economic factors that play a role in determining women's access to quality basic health care.

Name: Topics in Global Security
Description: Treatment of topics in global security. Can be repeated by students but not with the same content.

Name: Topics in Politics and Policy in the Global Economy
Description: Treatment of topics in international political economy and policy studies. Can be repeated by students but not with the same content. Enroll Info: Requisite varies by topic

Name: Topics in Culture in the Age of Globalization
Description: Treatment of topics in in culture in the age of globalization. Can be repeated by students but not with the same content.

Name: Topics in International Studies
Description: Treatment of topics in international studies. Can be repeated by students but not with the same content.

Name: Washington DC Sem in International Affairs Seminar
Description: Seminar explores current issues in international affairs and the ways in which different organizations, businesses, corporations, NGOs and IOS seek to address them. Open to participants of the Washington DC semester in international affairs program only.

Name: Senior Honors Thesis
Description: Individual study and research for International Studies majors writing theses for the honors degree.

Name: Senior Honors Thesis
Description: Individual study and research for majors writing theses for the honors degree; continuation of Intl St 681.

Name: Directed Study
Description: Graded on lettered basis; requires written cons inst.

Name: Global Studies Seminar
Description: Provides a small graduate seminar setting for an interdisciplinary survey of major approaches to the study of globalization. It aims to familiarize students with key theories, issues, and debates, as well as methodological tools. Topics will include global economy, environment, health, culture, media, development, labor, governance, civil society, science, technology, and geography.

Name: The Practice of Industrial Engineering
Description: An introduction to Industrial Engineering subject matter areas, problem types, and design/analysis approaches, techniques, and methodologies. Special emphasis on formulation and design alternatives for problem solving with opportunities for written abd oral presentations of project exercises. Not open to students with advance standing in I.E.

Name: Introduction to Combinatorial Optimization
Description: Exact and heuristic methods for key combinatorial optimization problems such as: shortest path, maximum flow problems, and the traveling salesman problem. Techniques include problem-specific methods and general approaches such as branch-and-bound, genetic algorithms, simulated annealing, and neural networks.

Name: Inspection, Quality Control and Reliability
Description: Inspection data for quality control; sampling plans for acceptance inspection; charts for process control. Introduction to reliability models and acceptance testing.

Name: Analysis of Capital Investments
Description: A second course in quantitative methods for analyzing capital investments in technological environments, both public and private. Replacement models; comparison of alternative investment models; risk analysis; case studies.

Name: Introduction to Decision Analysis
Description: Overview of modeling techniques and mehtods used in decision analysis, including multiattribute utility models, decision trees, and Bayesian models. Psychological components of decision making are discussed. Elicitation techniques for model building are emphasized. Practical applications through real world model building are described and conducted.

Name: Decision Making in Health Care
Description: Introduction to the use of decision sciences in health-care. Conceptual understanding of medical decision making and its tools including decision trees, sensitivity analysis, Markow (decision) processes, and Monte Carlo simulations with examples from the current medical literature.

Name: Human Factors Engineering
Description: Analysis and design of man-machine systems using human performance models and data. Emphasis on systems involving communication and control. Projects using digital and analog computer simulation techniques for system design.

Name: Human Performance and Accident Causation
Description: A systems view of accident causation, with emphasis on the human performance limitations important in industrial and other accidents. Models of causation, data collection systems, economic evaluation, and safety programs. Small group projects.

Name: Occupational Safety and Health Engineering
Description: Introduction to the principles of safety and health hazards in the industrial environment. This course provides engineers with the fundamentals of measurement, evaluation, regulation, and control of hazardous conditions, toxic substances, physical agents, and dangerous processes in industrial operations.

Name: Ergonomics in Service
Description: Analysis, evaluation and design of office systems. Sociotechnical, ergonomic and job design issues. Performance of ergonomic evaluations in offices. Design project required.

Name: Methods for Probabilistic Risk Analysis of Nuclear Power Plants
Description: Methods for risk and reliability analysis of engineered systems, particularly as applied in the nuclear power industry. Fault trees and event trees, Bayesian data analysis, probabilistic risk management. Some familiarity with nuclear plant safety systems is helpful, but not required.

Name: Design of Program Evaluation Systems
Description: Design of systems for evaluating the effectiveness (efficiency, benefits, costs, resource utilization, contribution) of socio-technical systems. Measurement, analysis and interpretation of results including implications for engineering research. Extensive case studies.

Name: Computer Methods in Systems Analysis
Description: Development of modeling concepts and analysis skills necessary to design, program, implement and use computers to solve complex systems analysis problems. Emphasis on applications. Searching, sorting, list processing, trees, networks. Applications to include critical path method, resource constrained scheduling, branch & bound methods, discrete event simulation. Special emphasis on user interface. Project.

Name: Advanced CAD/CAM
Description: Focuses on the state-of-the-art in CAD/CAM methodologies and tools for manufacturing applications such as wire-EDM, casting, sheet metal fabrication, rapid prototyping, tool and die making, and cost estimation.

Name: Occupational Stress
Description: This course examines the nature of occupational stress, what it is, how it is measured, its anticedents and its consequences, and its effects on human performance and health.

Name: E-Business Transformation: Design, Analysis and Justification
Description: Analytical and integrative approaches for e-business strategy formulation, analysis and justification and development of implementation roadmap. Emphasizes development of analytical reasoning and managerial thinking through creation of assessment tools and decision aids to guide various aspects of e-business transformation.

Name: Quality of Health Care: Evaluation and Assurance
Description: Implementation, oversight, and management of quality-oriented activities in health care settings. Overview of current and historical activities, approaches, and issues confronting health care related to quality assessment, assurance, and improvement.

Name: Proseminar in Engineering Psychology and Human Factors Engineering
Description: This required course is for engineering psychology and industrial engineering graduate students. This will be an inter-disciplinary seminar in which faculty from Psychology and the Human Factors Engineering programs will present their research and lead discussion of topics including methodological issues.

Name: Societal Risk Management of Technological Hazards
Description: Issues involved in decision-making regarding technological risks and risk management in areas such as nuclear power, hazardous waste disposal, and pollution control. Risk perception and cognitive biases; risk analysis and decision analysis; political issues in risk management; regulatory mechanisms; and risk communication. Selected case studies.

Name: Advanced Nonlinear Programming
Description: Conjugate convex functions and Fenchel-Rockafellar duality. Monotone operators and subdifferentials. Advanced methods for nonconvex problems, such as variational principles, generalized gradients, degree and index arguments, and multivalued ordinary differential equations. Applications to economics and operations research.

Name: Nonlinear Optimization II
Description: Rigorous description and convergence proof of various nonlinear programming algorithms. Nonlinear programming algorithms constantly being developed by researchers in the field. Concentration on the more important algorithms from the wide variety of existing ones. Emphasis on algorithms that can be proved to converge and are practical. Unification of classes of algorithms and convergence rates for some. Each student codes and tests one of the algorithms described.

Name: Seminar in Organization and Job Design
Description: Discussion of current theory and practice of job and organization design. Papers presented by students.

Name: Special Topics in Systems Design
Description: Subjects vary.

Name: Italian Language Abroad I
Description: First semester Italian language course taken on a study abroad program for which there is no equivalent on this campus.

Name: First Semester Italian
Description: For students who have not studied Italian.

Name: Second Semester Italian
Description: None provided.

Name: First Semester Italian Honors
Description: Accelerated course for honors students with no previous training in the language; oral practice, grammar, reading, & reading.

Name: Italian Language Abroad III
Description: Third semester Italian language course taken on a study abroad program for which there is no equivalent on this campus.

Name: Italian for Speakers of Other Romance Languages
Description: Accelerated development of oral, reading and writing skills up to a level equivalent to that of the end of second semester Italian (102). Instruction draws on features shared by Romance languages, with focus on distinctions particular to Italian. No previous knowledge of Italian is required.

Name: Fast-track Intermediate Italian for Speakers of Romance Languages
Description: Designed for experienced learners of Romance languages, this is an exciting, fast-paced course that will allow you to cover the equivalent of two intermediate-level college semesters of Italian.

Name: Third Semester Italian
Description: Class reading of modern Italian plays, novels, and short stories; study of idioms, conversation practice; review of grammar.

Name: Fourth Semester Italian
Description: Continuation of Italian 203, with more advanced materials.

Name: Italian Studies Abroad in the Humanities I
Description: Italian studies course taken on a study abroad program for which there is no equivalent on this campus.

Name: Modern Italian Culture
Description: A survey of Italian history, art, music, politics, and general culture from the Risorgimento to the present.

Name: Directed Study
Description: None provided.

Name: Directed Study
Description: None provided.

Name: Italian for Reading Knowledge
Description: For students with language proficiency and graduate students who wish to acquire a reading knowledge of Italian. Intensive grammar; readings from appropriate texts in the humanities, sciences and social sciences. Gives no language credit.

Name: Italian Studies Abroad in the Humanities II
Description: Italian studies course taken on a study abroad program for which there is no equivalent on this campus.

Name: Advanced Italian Language
Description: Development of accurate and nuanced capacity for expression in Italian and for understanding the spoken and written language. The course will also address Italian phonetics and phonology to develop accurate pronunciation.

Name: Writing Workshop
Description: Continuation of 311. Development of composition and editing skills with focus on grammatical accuracy, conventions, and rhetorical techniques for organizing information, presenting coherent arguments, and appropriateness of language to topic.

Name: Introduction to Italian Literature
Description: From its beginnings through the Renaissance. Readings and discussion.

Name: Introduction to Italian Literature
Description: Continuation of 321. From the end of the Renaissance to the twentieth century.

Name: Rome: The Changing Shape of the Eternal City
Description: Changing shape of Rome as a physical city and as a cultural metaphor from the Augustan age to the Renaissance.

Name: Topics in Italian: Study Abroad
Description: A course carried with a UW-Madison Study Abroad Program which has no equivalent on this campus.

Name: Corso Di Stilistica Applicata
Description: None provided.

Name: Introduction to the Romance Languages
Description: Introduction to structural similarities and differences apparent in major Romance languages (French, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish) and to their historical developments, with reference to basic linguistic features of each language: phonology, morphology, syntax, and lexicon. Does not count towards French major.

Name: Special Topics in Italian Literature
Description: Senior Proseminar; topics vary.

Name: Special Topics in Italian Studies: Culture, Film, Language
Description: Examination of an aspect of Italian studies: culture, film, language; topic varies.

Name: Special Topics in Italian Studies: Culture, Film, Language
Description: Examination of a particular aspect of Italian culture; topic varies.

Name: Italian Film
Description: General survey of Italian film and of the relationship between film and the other arts. Consideration of film theory and of the Italian and European socio-political situation in the context of film production.

Name: Advanced Interdisciplinary Studies in Medieval Civilization
Description: An integrated treatment of a specific theme, to be announced by a group of specialists in different fields.

Name: L'Ottocento
Description: Major currents and writers of Italian Romanticism; Foscolo, Leopardi, Manzoni.

Name: Il Settecento
Description: Il Settecento

Name: Il Settecento
Description: Continuation of 621

Name: Lineamenti Di Letteratura Italiana
Description: None provided.

Name: Lineamenti Di Letteratura Italiana
Description: None provided.

Name: Il Romanzo Italiano
Description: None provided.

Name: Il Romanzo Italiano
Description: Continuation of 635

Name: Il Rinascimento
Description: I: Il Quattrocento. Lo sviluppo dell'umanesimo; Poliziano, Lorenzo de' Medici, Pulci, Boiardo, e Alberti; II: Il Cinquecento. Ariosto, Machiavelli, Castiglione, Tasso.

Name: Dante's Divina Commedia
Description: Lectures on Dante's life and times, reading Divine Comedy, commentary, discussion, reports.

Name: Il Duecento
Description: I: A systematic study of the earliest literary texts in Italy; the rise of the love lyric among the Sicilian poets; representative narrative works. II: The development of the lyric from Guittone d'Arezzo to the poets of the Dolce Stil Nuovo (Guinizzelli, Cavalcanti, Dante).

Name: Senior Honors Thesis
Description: None provided.

Name: Senior Honors Thesis
Description: None provided.

Name: Directed Study
Description: Cr/N.

Name: Directed Study
Description: None provided.

Name: Lineamenti Di Letteratura Italiana
Description: Lineamenti Di Letteratura Italiana

Name: Lineamenti Di Letteratura Italiana
Description: None provided.

Name: Seicento E L Arcadia
Description: None provided.

Name: Independent Study
Description: None provided.

Name: Issues in Methods of Teaching French and Italian
Description: None provided.

Name: Seminar-Studies in Italian Literature
Description: None provided.

Name: Seminar-Studies in Italian Literature
Description: None provided.

Name: Individual Research
Description: In connection with the doctoral dissertation.

Name: Topics in Jewish Studies
Description: Special topics in Jewish studies. The topic is footnoted in the Timetable.

Name: Introduction to Judaism
Description: General introduction to Judaism covering the biblical, classical rabbinic, medieval, and modern periods.

Name: Jews and American Pop. Culture
Description: Explores the interplay between Jews and U. S. popular culture, covering such subjects as early 20th century vaudeville, the 'golden age' of Hollywood, rhythm and blues music, television, and stand-up comedy.

Name: The American Jewish Experience: From Shtetl to Suburb
Description: Surveys American Jews from the eighteenth century until after WW II, examining political behavior (radicalism, liberalism, and nationalism), class formation, social mobility, culture, inter-ethnic group relations, religion, and problems in community building.

Name: Introduction to Modern Jewish History
Description: The history of the Jews in selected parts of the world since the 17th century. Particular attention will be paid to the fact that this is the history of a minority group whose life unfolds in relationship to a larger society.

Name: Introduction to Biblical Literature (in English)
Description: Introduction to the literature and literary history of the Old Testament, Apocrypha, Dead Sea Scrolls, Talmud, and Midrashim.

Name: Elementary Topics in Jewish Literature
Description: Elementary-level topics course in Jewish literature.

Name: Elementary Topics in Jewish History
Description: Elementary-level topics course in Jewish history. Enroll Info: Requisite varies by topic

Name: Elementary Topics in Jewish Philosophy and the Arts
Description: Elementary-level topics course in Jewish philosophy and the arts.

Name: Elementary Topics in Jewish Studies: Social Sciences
Description: Elementary-level course in Jewish Studies; topics drawn from the social sciences and vary by semester.

Name: Bascom Course
Description: A low-enrollment course developing skills in critical reading, logical thinking, use of evidence, and use of library resources. Emphasis on writing in the conventions of specific fields.

Name: Introduction to Biblical Archaeology
Description: An overview of archaeology and its relationship to understanding the biblical world.

Name: The Jews, States, and Citizenship: A Sociological Perspective
Description: Introduction to historical sociology of citizenship through a comparative investigation of Jewish emancipation in nineteenth-century Europe, including social origins of emancipation, its consequences for the social organization and collective identity of Jews, and Jewish responses to emancipation.

Name: Yiddish Song and the Jewish Experience
Description: Explores Yiddish song as an expression of the modern Jewish experience from Eastern Europe to the US. Covers folk song, popular and art music. Music and readings together provide an analytical framework to examine cultural and historical issues.

Name: Yiddish Literature and Culture in Europe
Description: Exploration of European Yiddish fiction, poetry, folklore, and cinema, with a focus on works of the 19th and 20th centuries.

Name: Food in Rabbinic Judaism
Description: Rabbinic literature frames the fundamental attitudes for how Judaism relates to food. Students will examine the history of food in rabbinic Judaism. In addition, theories from the field of food studies will be applied to rabbinic texts.

Name: Yiddish Literature and Culture in America
Description: Exploration of American Yiddish poetry, fiction, theater, and cinema created by European Jews in the United States.

Name: Directed Study
Description: None provided.

Name: Introduction to Hebrew Literature
Description: Selected works for different periods and genres; class discussions in Hebrew.

Name: Introduction to Hebrew Literature
Description: Continuation of 301.

Name: Modern Jewish Literature
Description: Pre-modern Jewish society's breakdown, immigration, the challenges of integration and exclusion, and the establishment of new communities will serve as a backdrop for the analysis and comparison of Jewish literary texts written in Hebrew, Yiddish, German, Russian, and English.

Name: Yiddish Song and the Jewish Experience
Description: Explores Yiddish song as an expression of the modern Jewish experience form Eastern Europe to the US.  Covers folk song, popular and art music.  Music and readings together provide an analytical framework to examine cultural and historical issues.

Name: Prophets of the Bible
Description: An introduction to the thought, literature, and history of the prophets of ancient Israel (in English).

Name: King David in History and Tradition
Description: An exploration of the literary and historical aspects of the text of 1-2 Samuel + 1 Kings 1-2; the history and archaeology of Jerusalem during the tenth century B.C.E.; and the varieties of ways in which the figure of King David has been received in subsequent religious and secular literature, visual art, music, television, and cinema.

Name: Jewish Literature of the Greco-Roman Period
Description: Jewish literature from 350 BCE to 150 CE. The Greek and Hebrew sources include stories, religious poetry, wisdom books and apocalyptic texts. Readings (in translation) from the Apocrypha, Pseudepigrapha, and the Dead Sea Scrolls in their historical, cultural and literary setting.

Name: Jerusalem, Holy City of Conflict and Desire
Description: Jerusalem, the Holy City for Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, has become the center of religious, political, and national contention. This course explores the sources of the conflict and its development over the centuries, with the aim of illuminating the complex situation of the region and its implications for the world.

Name: Israeli Fiction in Translation
Description: Major writers, trends and themes in Israeli fiction from pre-State period to present. Meets with Hebrew Studies 343.

Name: Modern Political History of the Jews: Era of Mass Movements, 1870-1970
Description: This course will focus on Jewish socialist and nationalist political movements, analyzing their origins in imperial Russia in the late 19th century and their development in the Soviet Union, Poland, Palestine/Israel, and the U.S. in the 20th century.

Name: Jewish Cultural History (in English)
Description: Survey of Jewish cultural history from the Biblical to Talmudic and early Muslim periods; and its interaction with other cultures, including Hellenistic, Roman, and Muslim.

Name: Topics in Modern Hebrew / Israeli Literature and Culture I
Description: Readings in Hebrew literature, class conducted in Hebrew.

Name: Topics in Modern Hebrew / Israeli Literature and Culture II
Description: Continuation of 401.

Name: Intermediate Topics in Jewish Literature
Description: Intermediate-level topics course in Jewish literature. Enroll Info: Requisite varies by topic

Name: Intermediate Topics in Jewish History
Description: Intermediate-level topics course in Jewish history.

Name: Intermediate Topics in Jewish Philosophy and the Arts
Description: Intermediate-level topics course in Jewish philosophy and the arts. Enroll Info: Requisite varies by topic

Name: Intermediate Topics in Jewish Studies: Social Sciences
Description: Intermediate-level course in Jewish Studies; topics drawn from the social sciences and vary by semester.

Name: Jewish Philosophy from Antiquity to the Seventeenth Century
Description: A survey of major philosophers and philosophical currents within Judaism from antiquity through the seventeenth century.

Name: Moral Philosophy and the Holocaust
Description: Selected moral and philosophical issues raised by the Holocaust such as when and whom to rescue; includes issues arising after the annihilation such as forgiveness and reconciliation.

Name: Biblical Archaeology
Description: An examination of current problems, methods, and trends in archaeological research in the lands of the Bible.

Name: Topics in Jewish Studies
Description: Special topics in Jewish studies. The topic is footnoted in the Timetable.

Name: Biblical Texts, Poetry
Description: Critical reading of selected texts from the Minor Prophets and the Writings.

Name: Biblical Texts, Poetry
Description: Continuation of 513.

Name: Holocaust: History, Memory and Education
Description: This course explores the ways in which Holocaust history, memory and education are mutually entangled, politically charged and morally complex. Using primarily American sites of memory, students will critically analyze a variety of representations of the Shoah--in literature, films, memoirs, monuments, museums and classrooms.

Name: Anti-Semitism in European Culture, 1700-1945
Description: A critical review of major theories of anti-Simitism and a history of modern anti-Semitism.

Name: Readings in Contemporary Hebrew Literature
Description: None provided.

Name: Readings in Contemporary Hebrew Literature
Description: None provided.

Name: Jewish Literatures in Diaspora
Description: An exploration of Jewish literature in English and in Anglophone contexts.

Name: Literature of Jewish Identity in America
Description: The construction of Jewish American identity within American life.

Name: Advanced Topics in Jewish History
Description: Advanced-level topics course in Jewish history.

Name: Advanced Topics in Jewish Philosophy and the Arts
Description: Advanced-level topics course in Jewish philosophy and the arts. Enroll Info: Requisite varies by topic

Name: Israeli Politics and Society
Description: Course provides historical and analytical understanding of Israeli internal political life and institutions. Attention will be paid to political culture, coalition formation and ethnic politics as they are manifested in Israeli politics. The effect of regional conflict upon Israel's domestic politics will also be considered.

Name: Research Colloquium for Majors
Description: Colloquium for students conducting research under Jewish Studies 677, which must be taken concurrently. Discussion of problems that arise in conducting research, interpreting evidence, and composing an argument. Students will present research-in-progress for group discussion.

Name: Independent Research for Majors
Description: Original research project supervised by individual faculty; only for students majoring in Jewish studies. Topics depend upon student's interest and faculty member's expertise. Students must register concurrently in Jewish Studies 675.

Name: Senior Honors Thesis
Description: None provided.

Name: Senior Honors Thesis
Description: None provided.

Name: Directed Study
Description: None provided.

Name: Mass Media in Multicultural America
Description: An introduction to the roles and functions of print, film, electronic and digital media in multicultural America. International comparisons highlight differences and commonalities in the social and cultural position of mass media in societies with racially and ethnically diverse populations.

Name: Media Fluency for the Digital Age
Description: The media landscape has changed vastly over the last 20 years, and it has major ramifications for how we see the practice and professions of journalism and strategic communication. Through discussions in class and a group media fluency blog, students will examine and engage with this contemporary media landscape.

Name: Special Topics in Mass Communication
Description: Special focus on a specific conceptual issue or topic involving mass communication.

Name: Introduction to Mass Communication
Description: How the mass media are organized and how they function in modern society; their technological basis, economic and political foundations, and social implications.

Name: Mass Communication Practices
Description: Communication as a process involving sender and receiver, message and medium. Course provides students with a foundation of basic communication skills, helps students develop an appreciation of how different media influence the nature of information presented, and introduces students to technical skills.

Name: Principles and Practices of Reporting
Description: Basic reporting for print and electronic media. Students will bring together technical and conceptual skills by creating a variety of print, audio, and web-based news stories on a current public issue.

Name: Principles and Practice of Strategic Communication
Description: Introduction to strategic communication for students interested in advertising, public relations, health communications, and political campaigns.

Name: Introduction to Survey Research
Description: Theory and practice of survey research; planning, sampling, questionnaire construction, interviewing, content analysis, machine tabulation, analysis of data; two hours lecture; two hours lab or field work. Enroll Info: Not open to students with credit for POLI SCI 544 prior to fall 2017

Name: In-Depth Reporting
Description: Advanced reporting with emphasis on critical evaluation of evidence and on recognizing the complex effects of government actions. Students will explore and develop community context stories that originate in a range of venues from the courts to the schools.

Name: Interpretation of Contemporary Affairs
Description: Preparing and writing of editorials, columns and news analyses.

Name: Creative Nonfiction
Description: Creative elements of non-fiction story telling to develop skills necessary for writing across the journalistic spectrum, from newspapers to magazines to books.

Name: Multimedia Design
Description: This course focuses on visual communication and graphic design in multimedia contexts. Students build design and production techniques to relay creative messages through print and digital media. Content explores design theory and techniques, as well as the effects and ethics of visual media messages.

Name: Science and Environmental Journalism
Description: Instruction and practice in strategies for communicating science to the public. Emphases include (1) how to explain difficult concepts and prrocesses; (2) skills for telling interesting and artful stories; and (3) strategies for making reasonable judgments about scientific evidence.

Name: Magazine Publishing
Description: This course takes an integrated, in-depth approach to magazine management, writing, editing and design. It covers the magazine industry from both the editorial and business ends, bringing together journalism and strategic communication students. The course produces Curb magazine in print, online and mobile formats.

Name: Electronic News for Web and Broadcast
Description: News reporting, writing, and editing for the World Wide Web and for broadcast; includes interviewing, use of electronic equipment and presentation of webcasts, issues and problems in electronic news, production of webcasts.

Name: Investigative Reporting
Description: This class will teach the techniques of investigative and long-form enterprise reporting. Students will engage in extensive reporting in the field, and produce a final project.

Name: Creative Campaign Messages
Description: Introduction to the creative aspects of message development for advertising, public relations, and other strategic communications.

Name: Strategic Media Planning
Description: Introduction to media planning for students interested in careers in advertising, public relations, or other forms of strategic communication.

Name: Account Planning and Strategy
Description: Process of planning, implementing, and analyzing strategic communication campaigns.

Name: Digital Media Strategies
Description: Provides an overview of digital media from an objective, strategy, and tactical planning perspective within strategic communication media and promotion campaigns. This course is geared toward students with an interest in careers in advertising, public relations, or other forms of strategic communication. Because of the rapid growth of digital communications, students will benefit from knowing more about digital media whether working in account, media or creative at an agency or corporation.

Name: Public Relations Strategies
Description: Provides an overview of public relations from an objective, strategy, and tactical planning perspective within strategic communication campaigns. A depth course; it takes one core element of a strategic communications campaign, and provides an in-depth study into the topic area of public relations. This course is geared toward students with an interest in careers in advertising, public relations, or other forms of strategic communication.

Name: Special Topics in Advanced Concepts and Skills
Description: Exploration of a particular set of concepts and skills in more depth. Subject will vary.

Name: Introduction to Survey Research
Description: Theory and practice of survey research; planning, sampling, questionnaire construction, interviewing, content analysis, machine tabulation, analysis of data; two hours lecture; two hours lab or field work.

Name: Law of Mass Communication
Description: Freedom of speech and press with particular emphasis on major legal issues confronting media practitioners; introduction to such areas of law as censorship, libel, invasion of privacy, access to information, regulation of electronic media and commercial speech.

Name: History of Mass Communication
Description: Evolution of the mass media in the United States in the context of political, social, and economic change.

Name: Mass Communication and Society
Description: Relationships between mass communications and society; analysis and evaluation of media performance and of suggestions for change.

Name: Law of Mass Communication
Description: Freedom of speech and press with particular emphasis on major legal issues confronting media practitioners; introduction to such areas of law as censorship, libel, invasion of privacy, access to information, regulation of electronic media and commercial speech.

Name: Media and the Consumer
Description: Advertising and other mass media content from the consumer's viewpoint; consumer's need and opportunities for information, and use of opportunities; consumer evaluation of media performance, guidelines for effective use; alternative means for obtaining information; implications of consumer movement.

Name: Effects of Mass Communication
Description: Use and effects of mass communication for individuals and societies. Course examines who is affected, what effects occur and how much, what different media content is involved and what situations make effects more or less likely.

Name: Colloquium in Professional Communication Careers
Description: Weekly colloquium on current issues and career options in journalism & mass communication, featuring professional speakers from academia, industry, government, and the non-profit sector.

Name: Communication and Public Opinion
Description: The role of the mass media of communication in the formation of public opinion. Propaganda goals of government, political, economic, and social groups.

Name: Mass Media and Youth
Description: Children's and adolescents' use of mass media and mass media effects on them. Particular attention is given to changes in comprehension and other cognitive activities that give insights into media use and effects.

Name: Health Communication in the Information Age
Description: This course will examine the role of communication in health, how the revolution in information technology has affected health communication, and the assumptions about health information and communication that drive current efforts to use technologies.

Name: Mass Communication and Political Behavior
Description: Interrelationships of news media, political campaigning, and the electorate. Impact of media coverage and persuasive appeals on image and issue voting, political participation and socialization.

Name: International Communication
Description: Historical, political, economic and cultural trends in global mass communication systems.

Name: Mass Communication in Developing Nations
Description: Development, structure, and role of mass communication systems in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

Name: Media and the Consumer
Description: Advertising and other mass media content from the consumer's viewpoint; consumer's need and opportunities for information, and use of opportunities; consumer evaluation of media performance, guidelines for effective use; alternative means for obtaining information; implications of consumer movement.

Name: History of Books and Print Culture in Europe and North America
Description: History of books and print culture in the West from ancient times to the present. Focus on the influence of reading and writing on social, cultural, and intellectual life. Methodologies, theories, and sources for study of book and print culture history.

Name: Communication Research Methods
Description: Survey of methods for investigating mass communication process and effects.

Name: Social Networks in Communication
Description: Examines key concepts in social network theory and develops and applies them to the field of communication. Attention is paid to the differences between social and online networks, as well as their relationships. This class will explore major concepts and questions in social network theory and analysis, including the elements that make up a network; network relationships (e.g. homophily, knowing others like ourselves); the construction of whole social networks out of dyads (two people) and triads (three); strong and weak ties; roles and positions; groups, cliques, and clusters; as well as small worlds and communities. Emphasis will be on what these concepts mean and how they work. There will be minimal introduction to technical network analysis and hands- on work.

Name: Professional Responsibility in Mass Communication
Description: Explores concept of 'professionalism' in journalism and strategic communication, with emphasis on societal expectations for media and ethical systems. Applies theory to specific cases.

Name: Literary Aspects of Journalism
Description: Critical reading of the best reporting and writing.

Name: Community Service Learning: Technology for Social Change
Description: The course is an upper-level undergraduate/graduate service learning course that integrates the study of the social impact of new communication technologies into community engagement practices. The course will illuminate social, political, psychological, and policy implications of the adoption and use of new and emerging technologies and provide an educational opportunity to apply the knowledge and skills obtained from the class to a local, community-based collaborative project (i.e. integrated social media campaign) that aims to strengthen the community. This collaborative project is a hands-on experiment that demonstrates how to use new communication technologies for social change.

Name: Topics in Government and Mass Media
Description: Analysis of political and legal relationships between mass communication and government with emphasis on current problems and issues.

Name: Special Topics in Mass Communication
Description: Analysis of a conceptual mass communication issue in more depth than is available in existing courses. Subject will vary.

Name: Concepts and Tools for Data Analysis and Visualization
Description: Ours has become a data society. Like at no other time, our world--the natural world, from storm systems to diseases; governments and companies; and our conversations with friends and relatives, even our movements--is recorded in digital format. A few years ago, Google CEO Eric Schmidt famously stated that 'There was 5 exabytes of information created between the dawn of civilization through 2003, but that much information is now created every 2 days, and the pace is increasing.' (An exabyte is 1 trillion megabytes.) The result is that professional communicators in journalism and mass communication, as well as researchers and private firms, now literally have more data than they know what to do with. There is tremendous need across our society for people who are able to use data to investigate important questions, draw useful insights from those data, and communicate those insights to others--and also to be realistic and honest about what data can and cannot do. That is what this class is for: it is an introduction to the world of data, how data can be used to answer questions and those answers can be effectively and ethically communicated. More specifically, we will offer a combination of conceptual training, instruction in specific tools for data analysis and visualization, and the opportunity to put new skills to use in a final project. This course is intended for Juniors, Seniors and Graduate students and by instructor permission. Research methods experience preferred.

Name: Senior Honors Thesis
Description: None provided.

Name: Senior Honors Thesis
Description: None provided.

Name: Senior Thesis
Description: None provided.

Name: Senior Thesis
Description: None provided.

Name: Internship
Description: Students may earn no more than three internship credits as a part of their degree program.

Name: Directed Study
Description: None provided.

Name: Directed Study
Description: None provided.

Name: Advanced Mass Media Practice
Description: Advanced projects in professional practice in mass media. When course focuses on journalism, it typically emphasizes advanced projects in specialized reporting. Course is designed for professional-track M.A. students. Emphasis varies with instructor. Course may be repeated with different instructor.

Name: Mass Communication and the Individual
Description: Theory and research on individuals' use of mass communication and effects of mass communication. Topics include choice, selection and functions of mass media use, attention and cognitive processing, information effects, persuasion and emotion/involvement, and social and behaviroal effects.

Name: Mass Communication and Society
Description: This course examines systematic procedures for theory building and comparison of theories of communication processes between mass media and other societal institutions and their relationships with both individuals and micro-social systems.

Name: Conceptualization and Design of Mass Communication Research
Description: Assists students in turning research questions into substantive research designs with understanding of the concepts involved. For most students, the final product will be a well-developed thesis or dissertation proposal.

Name: Mass Communication History
Description: Intensive reading and discussion designed to introduce students to literature of mass communication.

Name: Conceptualization and Design of Mass Communication Research
Description: Assists students in turning research questions into substantive research designs with understanding of the concepts involved. For most students, the final product will be a well-developed thesis or dissertation proposal.

Name: Qualitative Communication Research Methods
Description: Course in research methodology designed to assist students to design research, analyze and interpret evidence, and develop a deeper appreciation of research strategies.

Name: History of Mass Communication
Description: Intensive reading and discussion designed to introduce students to literature of mass communication.

Name: Global Communication
Description: Readings and discussion focussing on global media issues. Topics may include news flow, cultural imperialism, representations, history and political economy, globalization trends, new technologies, mass media and nation building, communication and grassroots politics.

Name: Political Communication
Description: This course examines the role of communication in American politics. Topics covered include the communication of politics (e.g., communication by politics elites, effects of mass media and interpersonal communication on political attitudes) as well as the politics of communications (regulation of political communication, policy issues, etc.).

Name: Technology and Society
Description: This seminar considers the effects of new communication technologies on everyday life and political mobilization.

Name: Mass Communication and Culture
Description: Intensive readings focusing on the critical studies and/or cultural studies traditions in mass communication theory and research.

Name: Mass Communication and the Individual
Description: Theory and research on individuals' use of mass communication and effects of mass communication. Topics include choice, selection and functions of mass media use, attention and cognitive processing, information effects, persuasion and emotion/involvement, and social and behaviroal effects.

Name: Science and Environment Communication
Description: Course uses available scholarship and commentary to track the evolution of mass media coverage of science and the environment. Emphasis on how journalists utilize evidence, the influence of scientific and journalistic norms on stories, and the effects of mass media on science and environment messages to the public.

Name: Mass Communication and Societal Institutions
Description: This course examines systematic procedures for theory building and comparison of theories of communication processes between mass media and other societal institutions and their relationships with both individuals and micro-social systems.

Name: Topics in Mass Communication
Description: In-depth investigation of a specific topic in mass communication.

Name: Colloquium in Mass Communication
Description: May be repeated to a maximum of 3 credits. Colloquium series for communication graduate students. Course will offer research presentations by mass communication scholars, and is designed to acquaint graduate students with theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of communication.

Name: Graduate Teaching Colloquium
Description: Colloquium series for graduate students in fields related to communication and information studies. Course meets once per week for a teaching presentation by a guest faculty or staff member on various theoretical and practical approaches to teaching and learning in the communication and information fields.

Name: Thesis
Description: None provided.

Name: Independent Research Problems
Description: None provided.

Name: Exercise, Nutrition, and Health
Description: Guidelines and assessment methods for fitness and nutrition. Motivation, adherence and stress-reduction techniques discussed. Lecture-demonstration concerning effects of exercise and nutrition on health and well-being. Team-taught by faculty and staff with expertise in exercise physiology, nutrition, and psychology.

Name: Aquatics
Description: Attainment and maintenance of a high degree of personal efficiency in swimming strokes and proficiency in fundamental aquatic skills, and an understanding of the fundamental physiological, mechanical and kinesiological principles as they relate to aquatic performance.

Name: Physiology of Human Performance
Description: Humans are capable of achieving astonishing performances in athletics, in work and in other extraordinary situations. These extraordinary performances often provide important insights into physiological processes and their limits. This course integrates information from biology, chemistry, psychology, mechanics, etc., to understand the factors that determine and limit human performance from the molecular level all the way up to whole body movement. The emphasis in the class is on using case studies to investigate physiological processes underlying movement, exercise, and performance.

Name: First Aid and Basic Life Support
Description: Techniques and procedures to deal effectively with common emergencies. Includes training in airway obstruction, cardiopulmonary resuscitation, automated external defibrillation, injuries, and medical emergencies.

Name: Introduction to Kinesiology
Description: Introduces students to the field of kinesiology and the Department of Kinesiology at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Introductory material about physical activity and health will be provided, and career opportunities in kinesiology will be discussed.

Name: Foundations of Physical Education
Description: Introduction to physical education teaching, movement education, and an operational understanding of the scientific study of human movement. Lecture and lab.

Name: Living well: Lifestyle balance and health promotion for college students
Description: This course is designed to promote student's wellness as they manage college life and its demands. It examines health and well being related to college students' time-use patterns; balance among daily activities; daily routines and habits; circadian rhythms, energy cycles and sleep; self-care activities; and stress management. Students in this course apply course material to their own lives by participating in a self-analysis of their lifestyle, participating in mindfulness and other wellness activities, and engaging in a lifestyle balance project.

Name: Adapted Fitness and Personal Training
Description: Fitness class for developing individualized personal goals. Accommodates persons having temporary or permanent disability. Alternative to dropping from other program classes due to injury or other medical reason.

Name: Introduction to Athletic Training
Description: An introductory course covering issues and basic concepts regarding prevention, management, and treatment of athletic injuries. The role of the athletic trainer in the sports medicine field is emphasized.

Name: Introduction to Yoga Practice
Description: An introduction to yoga practice, philosophy, history, and traditions.

Name: Movement Techniques for Stress Management
Description: Use of movement strategies to develop skills for reducing tensions associated with stress. Stategies include neuromuscular relaxation,flexibility exercises and movement awareness techniques.

Name: Science and Practice of Resistance Training
Description: Lectures and demonstrations on the principles of resistance training and associated physiological effects designed for practitioners who wish to gain a detailed understanding of the science of resistance training.

Name: The Science & Practice of Marathon/Distance Running
Description: Advanced running course. Principles of long distance/marathon running are discussed and applied; provides a foundation for high level aerobic fitness. Lecture/discussion in areas of biomechanics, nutrition, training principles and programs, physiology, and running performance. Tempo/endurance featured throughout course. This course is intended for students who run 15 + miles/week.

Name: Choosing To Move: Constructing an Active Lifestyle
Description: Will promote physical activity at a level to achieve health benefits, particularly in students who currently are insufficiently active (less than 150 minutes each week of moderate intensity physical activity). Students will apply course materials (e.g., behavior change strategies) to their own lives by completing self-analysis of their physical activity levels and then developing a physical activity plan to increase current physical activity levels, as well as a plan to maintain the activity after the course has ended.

Name: Tai Chi Ch'uan
Description: Learn and practice 24-movement Yang Style Tai Chi Form and Animal Frolic Qi Gong Form

Name: Techniques in Athletic Training
Description: An applied clinical approach to basic skills commonly used in the field of athletic training. Designed for students interested in athletic training, and an appropriate elective for those who plan to teach or coach.

Name: Introductory Neuroscience
Description: Entry-level course provides a systematic introduction to the mammalian nervous system, with emphasis on the structure and function of the human brain. Topics include the function of nerve cells, sensory systems, control of movement, learning and memory, and diseases of the nervous system. The foundational knowledge covered in this course serves students interested in health sciences majors, as well as non-science students interested in neuroscience and its relation to human health, wellness, and disease.

Name: Introduction to Clinical Anatomy of Human Movement
Description: Designed to provide students with a foundational knowledge in musculoskeletal anatomy and anatomical considerations related to human movement and physical activity.

Name: Human Physiology and Health
Description: In this introductory course students learn basic physiological concepts, apply them to understand human health and disease, and link them to broader core concepts in biology. Each student completes a project in which they apply their conceptual understanding of general biology and physiology to investigate and create informational materials for the public about a disease or health promotion strategy. The foundational knowledge covered in this course serves students interested in health sciences majors, as well as non-science students interested in life-long health.

Name: Methods of Teaching Invasion Games and Sports
Description: An examination of differences and similarities of various invasion games.  Sequencing of skills and development of concepts to produce effective performance. Instruction in the teaching of invasion games to incorporate individuals of all ability levels.

Name: Kendo: Integration of Martial Arts and Liberal Arts
Description: Kendo practice (martial art) supplemented by lecture describing its historical roots and philosophical background.

Name: Practicum in Kinesiology
Description: Supervised experience in a specialized area of physical education.

Name: Advanced Techniques in Athletic Training
Description: A course to provide the future athletic training professional with a foundation in advanced athletic training techniques. Sample topics include: injury prevention, emergency care, orthopedic appliance applications, protective equipment, environmental considerations, and computer applications.

Name: Technology for Physical Activity and Health Professionals
Description: Designed to provide students with creative technology strategies in the fields of school wellness education, physical activity, and fitness management. Students will build skills for using widely available technology resources to enhance instruction, assessment, motivation, communication, and advocacy in health and fitness settings. Skill-specific units present experiential assignments that increase learner confidence. Each unit produces print or digital materials for practical professional use with an emphasis on innovation.

Name: Physiology of Exercise
Description: Fundamental knowledge about, and appreciation for, the adaptability of human physiological systems in meeting a range of exercise demands.

Name: Assessment and Research in Physical Activity Pedagogy
Description: Course topics and laboratory experiences will focus on parameters that are measured in physical activity pedagogy; instruments for measuring physical activity, health related fitness, knowledge, and psychological characteristics; concepts of assessment and research, basic statistical methods; and action research.

Name: Adapted Physical Activity
Description: An understanding of foundations, assessment and pedagogy for individuals with disabilities in a variety of physical activity settings. Emphasis on individual differences, life-span, and self-actualization.

Name: Evaluation and Diagnosis of Orthopedic Conditions
Description: The evaluative skills and knowledge needed for minimum competency in the recognition, evaluation, and diagnosis of orthopedic conditions common to active populations.

Name: Biomechanics of Human Movement
Description: Analysis of human action through the application of mechanical principles.

Name: Group Development and Behavior Management
Description: Provide students with opportunities and experiences to learn and participate in the development of groups. Provide students with strategies and experiences in the management of behaviors and techniques to maintain a safe and productive teaching environment.

Name: Current Topics in Outdoor Pursuits
Description: Introduce students to several outdoor activities to enable the teaching of these topics.

Name: Human Anatomy
Description: Lectures. Structure of the human body.

Name: Human Anatomy-Kinesiology
Description: None provided.

Name: Research in Kinesiology
Description: The research process as applied in kinesiology, including hypothesis development, ethical issues, study design, measurement and statistical concepts, and presentation of results. Includes exposure to current research within the Department of Kinesiology.

Name: Methods of Teaching Elementary Physical Education
Description: Theory, organization, and teaching; small group teaching in elementary schools.

Name: Human Anatomy
Description: Uses a regional approach to provide a foundation of knowledge in human anatomy. Units cover an introduction to anatomical systems; back and limbs; thorax, abdomen, and pelvis; and head and neck.

Name: Human Anatomy Laboratory
Description: Takes a regional approach to cover the gross anatomy of the human body in four units: introduction to anatomical systems; back and limbs; thorax, abdomen, and pelvis; and head and neck. A variety of tools, including interactive software, models, and specimens, will be used.

Name: Introduction to Exercise Psychology
Description: Emphasis on the psychological foundations of exercise with motivational techniques, perception of effort, personality dynamics, and mental health serving as the focal points.

Name: Health and Physical Education in a Multicultural Society
Description: Familiarize students with perspectives of culture and diversity, the concepts and importance of culturally responsive teaching, and the Act 31 requirement for teacher education students within a health and physical education/activity context. Students will have opportunities to incorporate concepts from class into their Multicultural Field Experience.

Name: Socio-Cultural Aspects of Physical Activity
Description: An introduction to the philosophy of physical activity/education, history of physical activity/education and sport, and sociology of sport.

Name: Therapeutic Strategies in Athletic Training I
Description: A study of therapeutic intervention strategies used by athletic trainers. Evidence guided principles and clinical applications of therapeutic exercise, use of physical agents, indications and contra-indications, program design, progression, and standard documentation.

Name: Therapeutic Strategies in Athletic Training II
Description: A study of therapeutic intervention strategies used by athletic trainers. Evidence guided principles and clinical applications of therapeutic exercise, use of physical agents, indications and contra-indications, program design, progression, and standard documentation. A continuation of Kines 357.

Name: Lifespan Motor Development
Description: (For majors) Motor development in individuals at various points in the life span; use of such information as a framework for assessing levels of motor development. How to observe movement, interpreting and using such information as one important basis for planning what and how to teach.

Name: Motor Learning and Performance
Description: A basic and up-to-date view of the major processes and mechanisms underlying the performance and learning of motor skills. Principles in motor learning and control are systematically introduced to produce a meaningful conceptual framework.

Name: Assessment and Programming in Adapted Physical Education
Description: Physical education methods, programs and assessment procedures related to individuals with a variety of disabilities.

Name: Practicum: Adapted Physical Education
Description: A practicum experience for individuals who are emphasizing the area of Physical Education/Special Populations. Six hours per week working with individuals who have disabling conditions.

Name: Planning, Teaching and Assessment in Physical Education
Description: Prepare the kinesiology student in organizing, planning, assessing and implementing developmentally appropriate learning experiences aligned with local, state, and national standards to address the diverse needs of all students.

Name: Methods of Teaching PK-12 Dance and Gymnastics
Description: Methods of instruction in movement concepts, educational dance and gymnastics. Students will gain practice in planning, teaching, and assessing home school students, as well as practice in assessing their own teaching. Students will apply concepts presented in Kines 370 Planning and Teaching Physical Education.

Name: Methods of Teaching PK-12 Educational Games and Fitness
Description: Address methods of instruction in motor skills, educational games and fitness. Students will gain practice in planning, teaching, and assessing public school students, as well as practice in assessing their own teaching. Students will apply concepts presented in Kines 370 Planning and Teaching Physical Education.
